subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] what's the differences between Shavian and Read
msgSnippet: ... It is my understanding that after experimentation with what were essentially chain letters which progressed around the globe to various parts of the
messageBody:
satnordameriko wrote:

> and what were the problems with Shavian?

It is my understanding that after experimentation with what were
essentially chain letters which progressed around the globe to various
parts of the British commonwealth and the U.S. with people adding
passages to the letters in Shavian, that Kingsley Read decided to make
the changes which resulted in the introduction of Quikscript. As to his
motivation, I believe he reached the conclusion that some of the letters
in Shavian and their proper use were not as apparent to other English
speakers as he had first thought they would be, i.e. the differences in
accent were greater than he anticipated. So QS is simplified a little
from Shavian. An example is that he deleted the accented schwa symbol.

Additionally, he must have decided after the initial experiments that he
could simplify the alphabet to make it faster to write. Quikscript is
strongly cursive although letters are attached only when one letter
naturally leads into another (there are a couple of exceptions to this).
Shavian letters, on the other hand, are not connected. Advocates of
Shavian insist that this does not slow down writing, but I cannot accept
this. If every new letter requires a penlift, it has to slow writing down.

Welcome to our site. I hope you find QS useful in your daily life. If
it helps you, pass it on to others.

Paige G.

satnordameriko wrote:

> and what were the problems with Shavian?

It is my understanding that after experimentation with what were 
essentially chain letters which progressed around the globe to various 
parts of the British commonwealth and the U.S. with people adding 
passages to the letters in Shavian, that Kingsley Read decided to make 
the changes which resulted in the introduction of Quikscript.  As to his 
motivation, I believe he reached the conclusion that some of the letters 
in Shavian and their proper use were not as apparent to other English 
speakers as he had first thought they would be, i.e. the differences in 
accent were greater than he anticipated.  So QS is simplified a little 
from Shavian.  An example is that he deleted the accented schwa symbol.

Additionally, he must have decided after the initial experiments that he 
could simplify the alphabet to make it faster to write.  Quikscript is 
strongly cursive although letters are attached only when one letter 
naturally leads into another (there are a couple of exceptions to this). 
 Shavian letters, on the other hand, are not connected.  Advocates of 
Shavian insist that this does not slow down writing, but I cannot accept 
this.  If every new letter requires a penlift, it has to slow writing down.

Welcome to our site.  I hope you find QS useful in your daily life.  If 
it helps you, pass it on to others.
 
Paige G.
